The latter contains descriptions for shortcuts for the table, such as the arrow up, down, left, right keys, or using ‚ÄúCmd + D‚Äù to delete.

Automatic Update of SAP Fiori Apps Upon Change of Data in Backend

There are quite a few cases where users would appreciate seeing absolutely up-to-date data in their application, so that the data is automatically updated if changes occur in the backend. These changes could be made by other users, or by automated background processing . An example for the latter is the Traceability Results application, which is now automatically updated if a batch run has created new traceability items.

Note that this only supported by applications built with SAP Fiori elements using OData V4.

Improved performance for scrolling in grid tables

Our engineers have done some magic so that now scrolling is very fast in grid tables, which are the table type typically used for working with large volumes of data.

Why do I call it magic? Well, modern web-based UIs have the UI layer running in the browser, managing direct user interactions, and calling services in the backend to get and update data. However, if you are working with a list of say over 100,000 items, you would have to wait quite a long time when starting the application until all items have been loaded into the browser. Hence we only load a certain number to start with, such as 100. This however means that when a user scrolls beyond the 100 which have been loaded, additional data needs to be fetched from the backend, which slows down scrolling. Now, our engineers have found a way to minimize this effect to almost zero, so that you have fast scrolling all the time ‚Äì magic!

Figure 25: Performance improvement for scrolling in grid tables. Alt Text: a short video showing scrolling through a grid table.

Whenever the threshold is reached and more data needs to be loaded, there is a very short delay, with the progress indicator being shown for a few milliseconds, as you can see in Figure 25. In most cases, this is completely negligible. Nevertheless, we do also provide customers the option to change the number of entries loaded by default when the application is started. This is useful if a customer knows that, for a certain application, the number of entries will not exceed 2.000 for example. Then they can set the threshold to 2.000, which means that the application will take a little bit longer to load first time around, but then scrolling will be instantaneous for all the data. Figure 26 shows the UI for doing this, as part of UI adaptation. The ‚ÄúThreshold‚Äù determines the maximum number of entries loaded when the application is started, the ‚ÄúScroll Threshold‚Äù determines the maximum number that are loaded during scrolling if new entries need to be fetched.

Figure 26: UI adaptation to determine the threshold determining the maximum number of entries loaded in a table when an application is started. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over ‚ÄúConfigure Table‚Äù with two new fields ‚ÄúThreshold‚Äù, being edited with the value 3000, and ‚ÄúScroll Threshold‚Äù, containing the value 300.

Table Grouping and/or ‚ÄúShow more per row‚Äù State can be Shared

If a user personalizes a table by grouping entries by one of the fields, such as the date, this grouping is persisted when sharing the link with a colleague: when the colleague opens the application with the link, they see the same grouping applied.

Similarly, if ‚Äúshow more per row‚Äù was selected by the user before sharing the link, the recipient will also see more information per row upon opening the application via the link. This information is also stored when saving a view of a table.

Sort or Group Tables by ID or Description

SAP Fiori apps display the ID and the description in the same column within a table, which provides a better experience than having them in two separate columns.

Now, we offer users a choice when sorting or grouping the table by a column which contains both ID and description: they can choose to do this by ID or by description. As you can see in Figure 27, this selection is very intuitive. The example shows what it looks like when sorting by Company Code. At the bottom of the table you see an entry ‚Äú1710 (BestRun US)‚Äù, where the Company Code (the ID) is 1710 and the Company Name (the Description) is ‚ÄúBestRun US‚Äù. In the popover ‚ÄúSort By‚Äù section, the row of icons next to Company Code and Company Name indicate that currently no sorting is active, with the option to sort either bei Code or by Name ascending or descending.

Figure 27: Sort or group tables by ID (in this case Company Code) or by Description (Company Name) when both are displayed together in one column . Alt Text: A screenshot of part of the Manage Journal Entries app, with a list of journal entries and a pop-over ‚ÄúColumn Settings‚Äù with two sections ‚ÄúSort By‚Äù and ‚ÄúGroup By‚Äù. The ‚ÄúSort By‚Äù section has two lines, ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù and ‚ÄúCompany Name‚Äù, and offers three buttons with icons for each of these, representing ‚Äúno sorting‚Äù, ‚Äúascending‚Äù, ‚Äúdescending‚Äù.

Hiding Description Fields in List of Fields in Table Settings

For tables as above where ID and description are displayed in one column, technically, the ID and description are stored in two different fields. Until now, when users personalize the table, both the ID and the description were listed in the list of columns, which confused some users.

Now, we have addressed this by providing the option to hide the descriptions (see Figure 28), and hence simplifying personalization. This option is on by default, i.e. the description fields are automatically hidden now.

Figure 28: Description fields can be hidden from the list of fields shown when personalizing tables. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over ‚ÄúView Settings‚Äù containing tabs ‚ÄúColumns‚Äù, ‚ÄúSort‚Äù, ‚ÄúFilter‚Äù, and a pop-over ‚ÄúFilters‚Äù with two options ‚ÄúHide descriptions‚Äù (selected) and ‚ÄúHide Unselected‚Äù (deselected) . ‚ÄúColumns‚Äù is selected and shows a list of columns with check marks. The third entry is ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù, followed by ‚ÄúCreated On‚Äù ‚Äì i.e. the description column ‚ÄúCompany Name‚Äù is not listed next to the ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù.

These are the highlights of our changes in details. For the full list of what‚Äôs new since the FPS00 shipment of the 2023 release, have a look at the What‚Äôs New Viewer:

  • What‚Äôs New for SAP Fiori launchpad for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

UI adaptation improvements for key users

We have made significant enhancements to UI Adaptation for key users with the 2025 release. The ‚ÄúAdapt UI‚Äù option which key users see in their user menu shows you what you can change in the app, in a very intuitive way. And you can change and adapt far more than in the past. See below for some highlights.

Also good to know: the Adapt UI menu entry is also available when using a Classic app (SAP GUI for HTML) from within the SAP Fiori launchpad. It will bring up the Adapt UI app for Screen Personas F5740 Adapt UI for Classic Applications with Screen Personas, which allows key users to adapt the layout of these classic UIs.

Key Users Can Rearrange ID and Description Within a Field or Column

SAP applications come with a standard arrangement of ID and description within a field or a column, based on user research. We have found that for financial users, it is usually best to have the ID first and the description in brackets: Company Code (Company Description), for example ‚Äú1710 (BestRun US)‚Äù as shown in Figure 27. For users in sales and logistics, it is usually best to have the name first and the ID in brackets: for example Customer Name (Customer ID), for example ‚ÄúUS Specialty Cycles 5 (USCU_S05)‚Äù as shown in Figure 2.

Now, key users can use UI adaptation to rearrange the order for a given application. Doing this change applies then to all occurrences of the field in the application, i.e. the filter bar, the table or in a form on an object page.

Far More Options for Key Users to Adapt UIs

Key users can now make far more significant changes to UIs than before. For example, they can add a button to clear all filter values in the filter bar, remove buttons such as the ‚ÄúExport to Excel‚Äù, and much more. Figure 29 shows the options for configuring a table for example.

Figure 29: Many more options for Key Users to adapt UIs. Alt Text: UI Adaptation is shown switched on for the application Manage Bank Hierarchies, with a popover called ‚ÄúConfigure Table‚Äù filling half the screen, and showing 12 options such as ‚ÄúEnable Table Export‚Äù, ‚ÄúFrozen Column Count‚Äù with a field for entering the number, ‚ÄúSorting‚Äù, ‚ÄúColumns‚Äù etc.

 

Design and Technology News

For a comprehensive overview of the recent design and technology news, have a look at my blog posts from Q1 and Q3 2025. These are also relevant for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA 2025 release, since the design and technology are already available in the cloud:

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
    Note though that the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard presented there is currently only integrated with for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

We are progressing at such a pace, that I have some additional news to share with you, not covered by the above posts. In addition, I would like to explicitly mention some particular highlights here from the above posts too.

Regarding extensibility: do have a look at the new SAP Extensibility Explorer.

SAP Design System Portal and UI Kits ‚Äì now with AI Components

We recently introduced the new SAP Design System portal that brings together the product design guidelines SAP Fiori for web, SAP Fiori for iOS, and SAP Fiori for Android, as well as to the new digital design system guidelines. With its enhanced usability, simplified versioning and improved performance, designers (and developers!) get a better user experience compared with the previous SAP Fiori design guidelines.

The new UI Kits available for designers in Figma make it easy for designers to design accessible UIs at enterprise scale, for web applications, mobile iOS and Android applications as well as wearables. The UI Kits provide reusable components for web and mobile, along with web floorplans, which give you what you need out-of-the-box.

We have just released SAP Web UI Kit v8.0 which includes a full set of AI components: AI Button, AI Menu Button, AI Split Menu Button, AI Prompt Input, AI Input, AI Text Area, and AI Rich Text Editor.

Figure 30: The SAP Design System portal start page (on the left), and SAP‚Äôs UI Kits for designers in Figma (on the right). Alt Text: Two screenshots. The portal page shows four main sections SAP Fiori for Web, ‚Ä¶ for Android, ‚Ä¶ for iOS, and SAP Digital Design System, each followed by links to UI elements, Figma kits, and overviews. The UI Kits show 8 cards, SAP Fiori for Android, Web, iOS, watchOS, Wear OS, Performance, Accessibility and SAP S/4HANA.

Find out more here:

  • New SAP Design System Portal for SAP Fiori Design Guidelines, and New UI Kits for Designers.

SAP Fiori Development Portal

I‚Äôm also happy to inform you about the new SAP Fiori development portal, introduced a few weeks ago. It is designed to help developers maximize the benefits of SAP Fiori elements for OData V4, which is more than just a UI framework: it‚Äôs a metadata-driven approach that leverages the SAP Design System as its guiding principle, incorporating the most relevant design system options for typical business tasks.

Figure 31: The SAP Fiori development portal. Alt text: A screenshot showing the Introduction page. On the left a menu has entries Using the Portal, Building Blocks, Global Patterns, Floorplans, SAP Fiori Tools. The Introduction page has a full width card ‚ÄúBuilding Blocks‚Äù at the top, with a description and tiles representing various building blocks. Below that ‚ÄúChoose Your Option‚Äù heading above two side-by-side cards for ‚ÄúFloorplans‚Äù and ‚ÄúCustomer Layout‚Äù, each with an image and description, and a ‚ÄúLearn More‚Äù button.

The SAP Fiori development portal puts building blocks front and center. These building blocks - such as tables, forms, filter bars, and charts - are orchestrated by SAP Fiori elements and form the basis of every OData V4 application. They provide standardized layouts and interaction patterns, ensuring UI consistency and boosting developer productivity. The great advantage of using building blocks is that you can use them to create a customer layout and yet still benefit from the advantages of the metadata driven approach: low code, built in enterprise-grade capabilities such as multi-language support, accessibility, security and performance, and design system consistency.

Find out more in this six-part series of blog posts, here is the first one, which contains links to the others:

  • Introducing the SAP Fiori Development Portal: Your Gateway to Rapid SAP Fiori App Creation (1 of 6).

Using AI to Develop UIs

The above posts from Q1/2025 and Q3/2025 introduced a number of powerful ways to accelerate UI development by using AI, such as:

  • Creating SAP Fiori elements apps from a sketch (in the Q1 post), now integrated in SAP Build Code and Joule (Q3 post)
  • Joule for SAPUI5 freestyle development (Q1 post)
  • AI-assisted auto-fix of coding errors with UI5 linter (Q3 post)

Recently, we have gone even further and introduced MCP servers for freestyle SAPUI5 development as well as for developing with SAP Fiori elements and the associated building blocks. These open-source Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers provide AI agents with comprehensive UI5 and SAP Fiori elements knowledge, including best practices and project-aware context information, and thus provide developers with valuable support. Figure 32 shows examples. 

Figure 32: Examples of the UI5 MCP Server (on the left) and the MCP Server for SAP Fiori (on the right) in action. Alt Text: both images show screenshots of a CLINE console view with a task entered as text at the top, followed by a list of steps which the system proposes to do to solve the task.

 Read about these new MCP servers in these blog posts:

  • UI5 MCP Server.
  • MCP Server for SAP Fiori.

Accessibility taken to the next level: WCAG 2.2 support

Accessibility is key to using SAP's business solutions. Adopting the latest standards gives applications a true cutting edge, ensuring that solutions are inclusive and meet the diverse needs of users globally. When creating apps with SAP Build and SAPUI5, developers can leverage the latest Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.2.

For example, two of the key new requirements in the 2.2 version are:

  • The minimum target size of an interactive element now needs to be 24x24 px, so that users don‚Äôt accidentally activate a neighbouring element.
  • Each operation that can be performed by dragging can also be performed alternatively without dragging ‚Äì so that people who cannot use a mouse to drag can still use the UI.

See more details:

  • SAPUI5 is Leading the Way in Accessibility with WCAG 2.2 

Blue Crystal and Belize Themes No Longer Available in the Web

As announced in April (Upcoming Removal of SAP Fiori Themes Belize and Blue Crystal), the visual themes Blue Crystal and Belize have been removed from our web UI technology with the 2025 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA.

 After upgrading, existing usages of Belize or Blue Crystal will be automatically redirected to the Horizon theme.

If you have created your own custom theme based on Belize or Blue Crystal using the UI theme designer, you will need to migrate this to an available theme. Our strong recommendation is to base the new version on the Horizon theme.

For more information about the web UI technologies affected, and how to migrate custom themes, have a look at this blog post:

  • Announcement: Removal of Belize theme of SAP Fiori.

Note that SAP GUI for Windows continues to support older themes, including Blue Crystal and Belize.

 

Final words

Come join us at TechEd 2025, November 4 - 6, either virtually or in Berlin, or at one of the TechEd On The Road events in Louisville (USA), Bangalore (India) and Sydney (Australia), to find out more about our latest user experience innovations. I myself will be in Berlin and Bangalore, so feel free to approach me after my talks if you have any specific questions. I‚Äôm looking forward to meeting some of you!

 This blog posts gives an overview of all the UX related sessions at all four events:

  • Exciting UX talks at TechEd ‚Äì Virtual, or meet us in Berlin and On The Road (USA, India, Australia).

 Please continue using the community to share your learnings and best practices, either by posting articles yourselves or via comments on this post. You can also follow me in the community if you want to be notified about further similar updates from me.

entry.title: JOIN US: Meet SAP HANA Cloud @ SAP TechEd 2025
entry.content:
Hi there! If you care about turning data into real business advantage, this one‚Äôs for you. TechEd airs next Tuesday, and our SAP HANA Cloud track is built to spark ideas, answer your toughest database and AI questions, and get you hands-on with the tools you‚Äôll use tomorrow. Join us in Berlin or online! We‚Äôd love to meet you!

üîπ Why this matters to you

  • If you‚Äôre responsible for data strategy, cloud architecture, or AI-enabled apps, SAP HANA Cloud is a central part of SAP‚Äôs Business Technology Platform and Business Data Cloud.
  • Expect practical takeaways: built-in AI capabilities, vector search and knowledge graphs, elastic compute for scale, and patterns for keeping your S/4HANA core clean while innovating fast.
  • This is more than theory ‚Äî roadmap sessions and hands-on workshops show what‚Äôs coming in 2025 and beyond and how to apply it right away.

üîπ Meet the experts and join our sessions (onsite in Berlin ‚Äî quick guide)

  • ST115 ‚Äî Strategy Talk: ‚ÄúSAP HANA Cloud: The Database for Business AI‚Äù
    Nov 5, 2:15‚Äì2:40 PM CET
    A high-level look at how SAP HANA Cloud supports analytics, multi-model processing, ML and generative AI ‚Äî and where we‚Äôre going next.
  • DA817 ‚Äî Roadmap Session: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs Next for SAP HANA Cloud: Roadmap and Innovation Highlights‚Äù
    Nov 6, 1:30‚Äì1:55 PM CET
    Roadmap reveals: generative AI toolkit, tabular AI functions, and features to connect your data to AI agents.
  • DA200 ‚Äî Deep Dive: ‚ÄúHelp future-proof your database landscape with SAP HANA Cloud"
    Nov 5, 10:15‚Äì11:00 AM CET
    Architecture-focused deep dive: elastic compute, file-based architectures, knowledge graphs, and integration patterns, to prepare your data landscape for the future.
  • DA201 ‚Äî Deep Dive: ‚ÄúAccelerating your AI strategy with SAP HANA Cloud‚Äù
    Nov 6, 9:00‚Äì9:45 AM CET
    How the In-Database AI, vector engine and knowledge graph engine enable context-rich AI scenarios via SAP HANA Cloud and SAP BTP.
  • DA202 ‚Äî Deep Dive: ‚ÄúExtensibility at scale: Building intelligent applications with SAP HANA Cloud‚Äù
    Nov 5, 1:15‚Äì2:00 PM CET
    Real-world approaches to clean-core extensibility using CAP and SAP Build Code.
  • DA261 ‚Äî Hands On: ‚ÄúUnlocking AI-driven insights from your business data in SAP HANA Cloud‚Äù
    Nov 4, 12:30‚Äì2:30 PM CET
    Hands-on focussing on working with tabular AI, similarity search, and RAG using the knowledge graph engine.
  • DA263 ‚Äî Hands On: ‚ÄúSAP HANA Cloud: Advisors and Automation‚Äù
    Nov 6, 9:00‚Äì11:00 AM CET
    Try advisors and automation features (ECN provisioning, partition/index advisors) that reduce ops overhead.
  • DA262 ‚Äî Hands On: ‚ÄúEnabling clean core development with SAP HANA Cloud and SAP Build Code‚Äù
    Nov 5, 3:30‚Äì5:30 PM CET
    Build side-by-side extensions with SAP HANA Cloud + CAP + SAP Build Code ‚Äî fast, scalable, and safe.

üîπ Tune in for our virtual sessions

  • ST115v ‚Äî Strategy Talk: ‚ÄúSAP HANA Cloud: The Database for Business AI‚Äù
    Nov 5, 6:30 - 6:55 PM CET
    A high-level look at how SAP HANA Cloud supports analytics, multi-model processing, ML and generative AI ‚Äî and where we‚Äôre going next.
  • DA817v ‚Äî Roadmap Session: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs Next for SAP HANA Cloud: Roadmap and Innovation Highlights‚Äù
    Nov 6, 1:30‚Äì1:55 PM CET
    Roadmap reveals: generative AI toolkit, tabular AI functions, and features to connect your data to AI agents.
  • DA201v ‚Äî Deep Dive: ‚ÄúAccelerating your AI strategy with SAP HANA Cloud‚Äù
    Nov 6, 9:00‚Äì9:45 AM CET
    How the In-Database AI, vector engine and knowledge graph engine enable context-rich AI scenarios via SAP HANA Cloud and SAP BTP.

üîπ Who you‚Äôll meet

Our speakers include engineers and product experts from the SAP HANA Cloud team, the people designing the roadmap and building the features you‚Äôll use. Bring your toughest questions; these sessions are designed for real dialogue and practical guidance.

Curious now? A few questions you‚Äôll leave with answers to:

  • How can genAI, knowledge graphs and agents change app behavior and search across enterprise data?
  • What does a vector & knowledge graph engine enable for RAG-style assistants?
  • How can elastic compute and automation lower costs and simplify scaling?
  • What are the best patterns to extend SAP apps without touching the core?

üîπ Onsite or virtual ‚Äî your choice

TechEd supports both formats. If you‚Äôre in Berlin, come meet the team in person, network, ask questions, and join hands-on sessions. If you‚Äôre remote, register for the virtual stream and get the same deep content and access to speakers.

üîπ Next steps

Register now on the SAP TechEd registration page and add the SAP HANA Cloud sessions to your agenda.
If you want a hands-on slot, sign up early! Those sessions fill up fast.

 

See you in Berlin, or virtually! ü´∂

entry.title: On-Premise Business AI Infrastructure for Small and Medium Enterprises Using NVIDIA DGX Spark
entry.content:
Disclaimer: this article is written without Generative AI, even for the proof reading üòä Enjoy the article written by human that is not common nowadays

Why Business AI?

That is what we always must start with. The business case should go first, for sure, and then we should evaluate possible deployment options, costs and security.

Statistics says that 95% of Generative AI implementations failed and that really scares the market in SAP enterprise software domain as well.

But let‚Äôs be honest, we are trying to sell Business AI anywhere as technology, forgetting about the customers, their uniqueness and their current pain points.

At Skybuffer starting from February 2025 (during the last 9 months) we have talked to more than 250 customers of different sizes presenting them Business AI technologies and discussing their use cases, or better to say helping them to find how Business AI can help their employees and partners to automate company‚Äôs workflows.

There are three main groups of use cases, as we see it now:

  • Direct interaction with SAP backend system via corporate messengers that brings simplicity and mobility at the same time. In many cases Creating or Updating data in SAP from mobile phones or via Teams brings real value.
  • Converting any unstructured data to knowledge, like SharePoint sources, attachments in SAP, support tickets. Mixing those things together, in different document original languages create real value for employees providing them access to the data that is hidden in most of the organizations.
  • Capacity heavy activities delivered by AI agents, especially helpful with emails data analysis, where the main data is always in attachments. Sometimes it requires to utilize OCR extracting data from scanned PDFs in those scenarios. Some excellent examples are processing vendors emails and posting invoice or service entry sheets into SAP or receiving emails from customers converting their external purchasing data to sales orders.

That is why SAP customers with any SAP backend system, either SAP ECC or S/4HANA, can implement Business AI today. I am not saying that it covers the entire Business AI implementation benefits, however, that is what we are focusing on now and helping SAP customers to allocate the benefits of using the technology.

Costs

In our opinion, Business AI is close to being the tool that must be deployed inside IT infrastructure, but a technology that is to being considered only if it returns the investment. Think about the indirect impact of missing Business AI in your business landscape. For example, consider the costs of hiring new staff because your employees are moving to other companies that utilize modern technologies. Why should they move? Obvious, because of the same reason we are all talking about Generative AI ‚Äì to stay competitive on the market.

However, costs of AI must be assessed carefully, because in most of the architecture approaches Business AI is a consumption-based solution. Risky, isn‚Äôt it? Of course! Consumption is hard to estimate, and it is also hard to avoid picks, so budgets of Business AI productive usage might be unacceptably high compared to the potential savings the technology brings. That is why we built Skybuffer AI as a solution with the double deployment options:

  • On premise, there is a clear and 100% predictable TCO.
  • On SAP BTP, this is a great option for CPEA contracts, for example, because in this case Business AI consumes the credits that are already paid, and we avoid extra costs for the infrastructure.

Why is DGX Spark in the article name?

Well, DGX Spark here is not because it is a buzz word now, for sure. That is because DGX Spark provides an excellent opportunity for small and medium enterprises to bring 15x15x12 cm GPU-unit to support their Business AI operations for a very compatible price. Actually, it allows us to keep both compute-unit and GPU-unit in the network avoiding data leakage and consumption-based costs. Excellent? Of course!

Here is how we use it deploying Skybuffer AI on premise:

Figure 01. Skybuffer AI deployment with GPU-unit served by DGX Spark

Criticism?

Yes, even writing this article I am already hearing the criticism üòä Guessing the comments like, ‚Äúthat is not for productive environment‚Äù, ‚ÄúDGX Spark tokens generation too low to serve even Small businesses‚Äù and many other sharp negatives. But let‚Äôs move back to the beginning of the article and understand the reason why I‚Äôve spent so much time talking about use cases first. Yes, now it is obvious that many mentioned use cases can be addressed by DGX Spark working as GPU-unit. Example? Easy!

Example #1: Vendor emails processing with data posting into SAP backend and saving originals (files) into the DMS (like SharePoint, Join, Google or whatever DMS is in use).

In the architecture mentioned above, Skybuffer AI allows almost out of the box creation of an AI Agent that will check, for example, Account Payable mailbox, read emails, analyze attachments, move them to DMS and create financial postings in SAP backend saving links to the attachments in DMS (either external or internal SAP DMS) on the SAP financial document level. In scenario, if we schedule the agent carefully, it can work in the almost synchronous 24/7 mode.

In case we schedule the Vendor Emails processing AI Agent with the limit to process just one vendor email in the minute, we will avoid pick system loads, and in this case, we can keep AI agent active 24/7. In such deployment it will be able to process 1 440 emails and create postings in SAP a day, that gives us 43 200 a month and amazing number of 518 400 documents a year!! All powered by one DGX Spark GPU-unit keeping the data on premise and avoiding cloud consumption.

That is what we call a proper deployment of Business AI. And Small and Medium businesses do not usually have such big number of documents from vendors, even the Cirque du Soleil does not have according to the latest SAP news post üòä What we usually do, we add extra Business AI scenarios to be processed by the same Skybuffer AI deployment.

Example #2: Automation of SAP user management services

Small and Medium businesses do use password-based login to SAP backend, so users keep locking themselves or forgetting their passwords. Do we need a powerful GPU-unit with the full size LLM to automate this? No, for sure. We can add those business scenarios to the AI Agent that is processing Vendor Emails üòä

Example #3: Bank data reconciliation

The same setup can be used to assist financial department to match bank transactions to the billing documents in SAP and post accruals for the cases that could not be reconciled, for example, those that miss billing data in SAP that is not created just because someone has forgotten to enter it or integration interfaces have data processing issues. DGX Spark GPU-unit provides particularly good enough capacity here as well.

Those are just a few examples that wind away the skepticism about the utilization of DGX Spark in productive environment.

Is it safe to invest in the on-premise Business AI setup?

If you need full control over costs and data security, the answer is yes. And we think that the answer is yes in general, because Skybuffer AI dual deployment capabilities gives companies the guarantee that on premise Business AI investment can follow their potential future cloud strategy. I am writing and hearing again ‚Äúwhat is this crazy man talking about! On premise investment can follow cloud strategies?? That is a paradox!‚Äù. And again, the answer is No, of course there is no paradox! If we look at the deployment of Skybuffer AI with integration with SAP Joule:

 Figure 02: Skybuffer AI deployment in SAP BTP with integration with SAP Joule

That is what we call real flexibility!

Sounds like a Gap Closing Solution?

Yes, that is the conclusion we have. There no hard choice anymore to run Business AI on premise or on SAP BTP, no prerequisites to start using Business AI, because the deployment in this article works with SAP ECC (down to 7.01 and even below), SAP S/4HANA on premise or SAP S/4HANA in private cloud. The only question must be asked, when we are talking about Business AI, is about the scenario the company should start with? You‚Äôve seen in our examples that Business AI deployments might bring benefits working in the scenarios that are independent from the historical data you have in your SAP backend and the historical data quality (sometimes it is called data silos), or scenarios that are independent from the version of your system and the point in time of your current digital journey. No need to wait for the upgrades, migrations, or other activities that sound like an act of catching a tail üòä. Just allocate some budget for Business AI deployment, for example, on-premise deployment on DGX Spark that is very affordable, and get the positive feedback from your employees or business partners and enjoy your business workflows simplifications.
